column2: Bootstrap Like a Web Developer
What you'll do
Level up your Bootstrap game and work with real files like real Web Developers.
Hiya, {{user_name}}! Let's keep the learning juices flowing and level-up your web development skills. In this activity, we will learn how to link files for Bootstrap to work.

We're going to pick up where we left off from the first Bootstrap quest so that we can focus on the most important parts. If you haven't gone through the first Bootstrap quest, we highly recommend that you work through that activity first.

Great! Let's get started. We've added the files you're going to use in the myproject folder. Let's take a look at the files. The lower-left corner of the screen with the icons is called the taskbar. Click the yellow folder to launch the file explorer. Click the Documents link on the left panel of the window and open the myproject folder. The folder should contain the index.html file and three folders: css, images, and js.

The images folder holds the images you will be using, the CSS folder holds all of the styling files, and the JS folder contains all of the Javascript files needed for your site. Let's take a look at the page we'll be using in this activity- right-click on the index.html file, and select Open With Google Chrome. If you are using a Hack computer, use two fingers and click on the mouse pad to right-click.

Super! During load-time (when the page is loading), Chrome is using the internet to pull in (or import) the Bootstrap code from another location for your project. What happens to the webpage when there's no internet to get those files? Let's turn off your Wi-Fi and see what happens.
Turn off your Wi-Fi by clicking the battery icon located at the bottom right corner of the screen, click Wi-Fi Settings, and click Turn Off.

Refresh the Chrome project browser by pressing ctrl + shift + r The browser tab that says *Hello, world!" is your project browser. Oh no! Without the code in those Bootstrap files, Chrome wasn't able to build your page properly. Let's fix your website.

Open the index.html file in your project folder by clicking the yellow folder in the taskbar located at the bottom left corner of your screen, click the Documents link on the left panel, and open the myproject folder.

Using Sublime Text, we can open the index.html file and fix the code to return it to glory. Right-click on the index.html file and click Open With Other Application. If Sublime Text is already selected, click on it, and then the Select button at the top right corner of the window. Otherwise, click View All Applications, click Sublime Text, and click the Select button at the top right corner of the window.

Great! Sublime Text should launch with the code for your website. Take a look at your code and try to guess why your website broke after we turned off the internet. The page doesn't load properly because we are using links that point to files on the internet. Let's find and fix those links.
On line 9, delete all the text after href= but keep the last >. For example, Line 9 should look like <link rel="stylesheet" href=>

Awesome! We will add code to tell Chrome to look for the Bootstrap CSS files in the CSS folder on your computer. After href= on line 9, type in the following "css/bootstrap.min.css" So, line 9 should look like <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/bootstrap.min.css">

Save your index.html file by hitting ctrl + s You'll know the file saved when the (.) on the tab turns into an (x). Return to the Chrome browser by clicking the Chrome icon at the taskbar. Let's see what happens.
Refresh the Chrome project tab, and the stying for your page should return. We're not done just yet because the carousel at the top isn't moving. Let's keep working on the site.

Go back to Sublime Text by clicking the grey box with the S taskbar located at the bottom left corner of the screen. Similar to the first link you fixed earlier, lines 89 and 93 also points to an external website. Let's fix those too.
We're almost done. For lines 89 and 93, delete all of the text just after src=" but keep *></script>. For example, the likes should look like <script src=></script>

Super! Let's tell Chrome where to find the jQuery file on your computer. Type in the following after src= js/jquery-3.4.1.min.js So, line 89 should look like <script src="js/jquery-3.4.1.min.js"></script>
For line 93, type in the following after src= js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js So, line 93 should look like <script src="js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"></script>
Save your index.html file by hitting ctrl + s You'll know the file saved when the (.) on the tab turns into an (x).
Return to the Chrome browser by clicking the Chrome icon located at the bottom left corner of the screen and refresh the Chrome project tab. Let's see what happens.

You did it! By completing this activity, you learned how to create an HTML website using Bootstrap and link downloaded files from your computer to make it work. You've leveled up your skills as a Web Developer! Now, try using different Bootstrap components to add more content to your site and personalize it. Make it your own!

When you're done, take a screenshot of your work by pressing the prt src button next to your Hack's power button. It is automatically saved to your Pictures folder. Finally, share your pic on social media and tag us using #MadeToHack.
